intro: Eriogonum villiflorum, commonly known as the Sierra sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its gray-green foliage and clusters of small, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in dry, sandy soils and is often found in mountainous regions. It is a member of the Polygonaceae family, which includes plants known for their distinctive leaf structures. Eriogonum villiflorum plays an important ecological role by providing nectar for pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
